GUEST COMMENTS: A rapid climate change can be dangerous. But it is the slow climate change that has characterized our globe.
06 Nov 2019, 18:00 by Erik Tunstad
Norway is obsessed with the climate. Everything we do and experience - the demolition of the Y-block, a new building at the Glomdalsmuseet or the number of cabriolets in Stavanger - must be put in a "climate perspective". It is therefore time to put the climate into perspective.
Before we start: The climate is changing. If it changes too quickly, it can be dangerous.
But first: "The globe is boiling!" Climate-scared children have shouted it, journalists have written it, Al Gore has said it - and everyone "knows" it: The globe is boiling!
This is a slogan that makes us think that if it gets warmer now, then it will be impossible to live here. Fortunately, that is not true. The globe has never been colder than now.
In more than 80 percent of life's history, the globe has been warmer. There have been deciduous forests on both the South and North Pole. 50 million years ago stood the rainforest in Germany.
The man-made climate effects we are trying to combat come on top of these natural ones.
The cold period we are in now began 30 million years ago, the great icing in the north began 2 million years ago, and the cycles of icing and gentle intermediate times will last for hundreds of thousands of years - or very much longer.
The global cooling arose for several reasons. The sun's heat varies, the Earth's orbit varies, the continents' location varies - and thus ocean currents, erosion, COâ‚‚ in the air - and the greenhouse effect. Certain combinations of these variables make the world cold.
The man-made climate effects we are trying to combat come on top of these natural ones.
Rapid climate change will threaten species
If you ask professionals, you will find that nobody denies that the climate is always changing and that the globe has been warmer in the past.
This, just as a comforting backdrop for those who fear that the ominous, red-colored weather forecast has begun to use to illustrate mild good-weather days, means that the greenhouse effect is transforming the world into ash and Sahara. The globe does not boil, and will not. Life has shown the opposite, it both withstands and prefers to be warmer.
What we are afraid of, however, is that the climate will change too quickly. Life on earth is adapted to the climate we have today, and although life itself can withstand more heat, some of today's species may struggle. That is why we try to reduce COâ‚‚ emissions.
I will not touch on the further climate debate - my point is that we must have a realistic picture of where we stand. We are trying to create a safe climate future - the question is whether such a thing exists, in some version of reality. The climate is always changing, whether we like it or not - and it is never safe. It has led to mass extinctions many times throughout the history of life.
The ice will come back
Today's unclear climate situation may cause us major problems, or they may become smaller. But what do we do when the globe no longer "boils" but rather freezes?
We are currently in a mild middle age. The only thing we can say for sure about the future is that in a few years large parts of the globe will once again be buried under three kilometers of steel ice. No matter what we do - sooner or later the cold will return.
Neanderthals


Reconstruction of a Neanderthal at the Neanderthal Museum in Mettmann in Germany, in modern clothing. This species - different from humans - survived more than 20 ice ages, but was eventually exterminated by cold climates for approx. 35,000 years ago.ğŸ“· Martin Meissner, AP / NTB scanpix

I have spent the last few years studying the climate of the past in some detail. The reason is that, with my wife, I will soon be publishing a book about Neanderthals, homo neanderthalensis. They died out, partly because of the climate. But not of a boiling globe - they froze to death.
Modern people's arrival in Europe, of course, also had something to do with the matter, but what strikes scientists is the strain the extremely unstable climate must have been in recent years before the Neanderthals disappeared some 35,000 years ago.
At that time, they and their predecessors had lived in Europe for more than a million years. During these more than a thousand millennia, they experienced violent fluctuations - from the mild and hot to the unbearably cold.
As we understand, this was because the Neanderthals lived in the same ice age as us, and they survived at least 20 rounds on the following carousel: They could first enjoy a Europe of elephants and rhinos, lions and leopards - France resembled an African savanna. Then, after ten to fifteen thousand years, it gradually became colder. Elephants were replaced by woolly mammoths, the forests turned into tundra - the Neanderthals froze - before turning around, and Europe became almost uninhabitable.
The ice was then left for ten thousand years before the world slowly thawed - and after a few more millennia the Neanderthals could once again wander under deciduous trees, enjoy the butterflies' dancing and slumber in the grass, while Africa's wild beasts announced their return.
Then it took a few years before it all turned again - it was time to settle for the next round.
The recent icing turned out to be too hard for them. Probably because they no longer only had the temperatures to fight against, but also our ancestors, homo sapiens - who survived, and thus became us.
Both and
No one knows how hard our next winter will be. But we know that it will come and that it will last for ten thousand years.
Shall we despair? Not necessarily. We have an advantage the Neanderthals lacked - advanced technology. Maybe it will be possible to live in a Norway under 3000 meters of ice? Maybe we can find a way to warm the globe? Or maybe we have to flee south?
This is whatever a thought we should have in mind, while we - for good reason! - trying to remedy our biggest climate sins. But somewhere in the back of our minds we should have the knowledge that the globe will inevitably freeze again. The cycle has been going on for millions of years. Maybe start the next round next year? Maybe in a thousand years?
